dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a LITTLE GIRL dancing around in a grainy super 8 h movie. A LITTLE BOY wearing a monster MASK enters the fra He struggles to lift a double barrel shotgun. He points i at the girl and pretends to SHOOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering slowly) Once I had a cat, he was the sweetest  little guy. Then one day he got sick  and died. My heart was broken. My  whole body hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues dancing. The little boy imitates her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that, I saw things differently,  everything could be summed up with  three simple words... fuck the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera swings over to some ugly, toothless relations  watching the show. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We open on a dark, lonely stretch of two lane blacktop. Off to the side of the road we see a rundown gas station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, welcome back to 93.5 WJRC's  Halloween monster weekend. I'm Jimmy  Ray and I'll be bringing you the  oldies, the goldies and sometimes  the moldies. The good, the bad and  the uglies straight from the WJRC  vaults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weathered wooden sign proclaims CAPTAIN SPAULDING'S WOR OF MONSTERS AND MADMEN, sits atop the building. A smaller sign below reads FRIED CHICKEN AND GASOLINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, kids still trying to decide on  the right costume? Well why not head  on down to Randall's Penny Save  located on Kimball Rd. just off route  1 in Mackin County. Choose from a  wide array of ghosts and ghouls,  jeepers and creepers... (scary sound effects) ...everything you need for your  Halloween needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHERIFF HUSTON, a tall southern good old boy, leans again his dusty cruiser smoking a cigarette, pumping gas into h tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside is a poorman's Ripley's Believe It or Not. Bizarre props and treasures of killers and monsters cover the dirty walls. Wax figures of JACK THE RIPPER stand gua before oil paintings by JOHN WAYNE GACY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright let's get back to our monster  music marathon with this classic  called The Teddy Bear's Picnic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perched on a stool behind the counter sits CAPTAIN SPAULD a crusty looking old man in a filthy clown suit and smear make-up. The word LOVE is tattooed across his right knuck and HATE is tattooed across the left. He is reading the newspaper, crunching on crackers from a paper bag and halfheartedly listening to a small, nerdy m wearing coke bottle glasses named STUCKY. Stucky thumbs through a stack of autographed 8x10 photogr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking through  voicebox in his throat) I... I got back a stack today. Some  nice shots. (holds up a picture  of June Wilkinson) See, a good topless June Wilkinson...  unfortunately she personalized it... (looking at the photo) to Stucky, love June.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, this ain't worth nothing now  that my name gotten all over it. I  was a fixin' on trading it to Jackie  Cobb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The retard over at Molly's fruit  stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's all hot on her after he  found some of his dad's old nudie  books hidden in the basement. He  keeps 'em taped inside his school  workbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spaulding brushes cracker crumbs off his paper and contin reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kid is one horny retard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, ain't they all. All them  retards wanna do is fuck and eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah... I think that if you  knew him... I mean if you'd understand  his urges, shit the guy's like forty  or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worse than a fucking rabid baboon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess, you know next to  wacking his weasel his other favorite  thing is twisting sharpened pencils  in the corner of his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, doesn't hurt himself, just  spins it around next to his eyeball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure that ain't the only place  he's sticking those pencils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, he don't do anything else with  'em, but he did get caught once with  a Planet of the Apes doll hanging  out his asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Goddamn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had to take him to the hospital. Kid  had Dr. Zaius stuck half way up his  butt, couldn't get it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always loved that mute broad that  Chuck Heston was shacking up with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nova, yeah she looked pretty sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, now there's the perfect woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get some stamps off ya? (slapping down his  money) Did you fix the toilet yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opens a drawer and tears off five stamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I did... so don't you go stuffin'  any goddamn paper towels down that  hole. I just snaked the shit out of  that thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spaulding SLIDES the KEY attached to a cow skull across t counter. Stucky grabs it. Spaulding hangs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya hear me? You bust that crapper  and I'll beat your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets go of the key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a STRANGER'S POV we watch through the window, Stucky EXIT for the restroom. Sheriff Huston finishes pumping his gas, gets in his crui and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All clear. Let's go shopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From this POV we RACE across the highway towards the fron door of the MUSEUM. SLAM! We BURST through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment of impact. BOOM. The door SMASHES open.   Spaulding's head JERKS up to see: a masked gunman, KARL,  wearing a LEATHER S+M MASK. Behind him stands a second gunman, RICH, wearing a rubber CAVEMAN MASK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary fucking Moses. Get the fuck out  of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, clowney. Keep your paws  where I can see 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, don't move or I'll blast a  hole the size of a Kansas City melon  through your ugly-ass Bozo face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spaulding obeys and raises his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go get that other asshole out of the  shitter and drag his ass back in  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miserable little cunts with guns. I  ought to jump right over this counter  and bash your fucking balls in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killer Karl steps up and puts his gun against Spaulding's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright Tippy, hand over the cash  box and I might leave your brains  inside your skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spaulding smiles wide, his teeth are yellow and rotted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spaulding's foot kicks a red switch, triggering a silent  alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you bitches need. A  reality check courtesy of my boot in  your ass. That'll be a fucking cash  box you can cry to mamma about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silent RED LIGHT FLASHES. In the dim glow, we see RAVEL a large hunched figure, sitting on the edge of a bed. The figure is heavily bandaged. Ravelli reacts to the flashing light, he RISES and puts a huge mask over his head. He EXITS the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stucky sits on the toilet pasting stamps on large yellow  envelopes. Killer Rich KICKS OPEN the stall, GRABS Stucky by the nec and PULLS him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, fatboy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move around the outside of the building watching the s inside unfold. HEAVY BREATHING is heard. Rich DRAGS Stucky into the main room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karl grows increasingly HOSTILE, knocks a candy display o raises his gun over his head and fires into the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) That's it. I'm gonna count to ten  and you're gonna hand over the cash  or I'm gonna splatter your grease  paint mug across the stateline...  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man. Just shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recognizing Rich's  voice) Hey, I know you. We were in high  school together. Wood shop, right?  ...Richard Wick... right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks nervously at Stucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, shut up, shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet down... three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck your grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remember Mr. Alacard the  shop teacher use'ta call you Little  Dick Wick. Hey, wasn't there a song  we made up to go with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (temper rising) Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Little Dick Wick, play with his prick  Don't his smell, just make you sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Ravelli's POV we watch through the window, as everyb inside starts SHOUTING at each other. Suddenly, Rich SHOOTS Stucky. Stucky FALLS BACKWARDS agai the wall, screaming in pain. We move QUICKLY towards the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly... CRASH! Ravelli SMASHES through the front door knocking Karl to the ground. In the light we see that Rav is wearing an OVERSIZED CLOWN HEAD. In his hand is a  sledgehammer. Rich TURNS toward the COMMOTION. The Captain quickly WHIP OUT a GUN and FIRES. Rich falls dead. Ravelli lunges at Karl, smashing him over the head with t hammer. Ravelli's clown head comes loose and falls to the floor. We now see that Ravelli is a bald pitbull of a man with badly scarred skin that is painted white and red. Karl hits the floor and begins CONVULSING violently. Spaulding STEPS DOWN from behind the counter, puts his fo on Karl's throat and points his pistol at Karl's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And most of all... fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOM! Spaulding SHOOTS Karl in the head. The screen EXPLODES RED, then TURNS BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it, that motherfucker got  blood all over my best clown suit.

dialogues.speaker: CREDITS ROLL
dialogues.text: Strange paintings of demons, monsters and bizarre creatur fade up and move across the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a BILLBOARD painted on the side of an ABANDONED TR The sign reads GOD IS DEAD. We turn to face the road as a car drives by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then, out of all of Charlie's  chicks who do you think is the  hottest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast food wrappers and road maps clutter the car's dashbo a swinging monkey head dangles from the rear-view mirror. Behind the wheel, the driver, BILL HUDLEY, 29, downs the  last sip of coffee before crumpling the paper cup and pla it among the other trash before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess if I had to choose I'd say...  mmmmmm... Sandra Good. She seemed  like a nice girl, I mean in a psycho  kind of way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beside him rides, JERRY GILMORE, 30, slumped down in his  seat, reading a magazine with a flashlight, feet hanging the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Huh, I thought for sure you'd  say Lynette Fromme. She's got that  snooty vibe I know you dig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sqeaky! No way, she ain't that hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's pretty cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah but, she reminds me of this  chick that I remember from fourth  grade... called a... shit, what did  we call her? (thinks for second) Oh yeah, Patty Pee-pee Pants... when  ever she got called on by Miss  Chumski, this chick would piss in  her pants and start bawling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) There always one kid with no bodily  controls. We had this dude, Jeff  Baxter, he was a puker. The fucker  would just sit there puke all over  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better than pissing... anyway so,  what's your choice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we're talking cute... like regular  cute, I'd say Leslie Van Houton, but  cute ain't hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, no shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far a hot... goes I gotta go  with... Ruth Ann Moorehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I forgot about her. She was  pretty hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck yeah, she is. I'd join a cult  to get some of that... and the best  part is she didn't try to kill the  President or nothing, so that baggage  ain't hanging around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought she tried to murder a  witness for the prosecution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll let it slide, she was only  seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude, talk about baggage, that ain't  no carry-on shit, that's some heavy  duty Samsonite shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess... hot chicks are always  nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot has got nothing to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONE FIGURE in a cheap skull mask and white robe stands hidden behind a billboard off to the side of the road. Bi car drives past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yawning) Hold on, I've heard this before...  but I can't remember the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, the guy goes to Hell and the  devil says, "do you smoke?" The guy  say, "yeah"... the devil say, "great  cause Tuesday is cigar night, sweetest  Cuban cigars you ever had."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, we really need to find some  gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not listening) Then the devil asks, "do you drink?"  Guy says, "yeah"... devil say,  "wonderful, Wednesday is free drinks  night, best booze you ever had...  all made from the finest stuff."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then the devil says, "are you gay?"  Guy says, "fuck no"... Devil says,  "Well then, I guess you're gonna  hate Thursdays."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I remember now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, no shit I just told ya. (looking at magazine) Hey, you think this place called  Alien Ed's UFO Welcoming Center is  still around? It says, "Where the  Fact is separated from the Fantasy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... we'll ask around as we  get closer. Man, I really don't want  to run out of gas out here in the  middle of Petticoat Junction, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up) Don't panic yourself, way too much  caffeine guy... I see a sign. (reading the sign) Captain Spaulding's Museum of Madmen  and Monsters... cool. Also... fried  chicken and... gasoline... next exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope this place is cool. We could  use something interesting to liven  up chapter 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car drives past. We turn and hold on the billboard. W see the happy smiling face of a young Captain Spaulding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up to one of the gas pumps. Bill and Jerry out. Inside we see Spaulding, now in army pants and a hun jacket, mopping the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pump the gas. Go inside and see  if it's worth thinking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (salutes) OK, Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry walks inside and immediately comes back out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy crap. You gotta see this place.  It's awesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How awesome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really fucking awesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up the chicks and bust out the  camera awesome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry sticks his head back inside the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wakey, wakey, eggs and bakey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark haired girl, DENISE WILLIS, 27, sleeps curled up u a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, babe. Me and Bill found a  kick ass place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grab Mary and come inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise shakes a lump of jackets and sweaters lying next t her. She removes a sweater from the top of the pile to RE the face of MARY KNOWLES, 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on sleeping beauty, time to go  to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half asleep) Sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rise and shine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groggy) No please, let me sit this one out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (removing the blanket) Let's go. You're the one who wanted  to be a photographer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I resign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late. You're in for life, let's  move it out Private Shutterbug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening her eyes) Christ, I hope this isn't more crappy  folk art. It's so quaint... it's so  primal... it's so crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, it ain't crap... it's... cute. (sarcastic) ...and really who are we to judge  the artistic merit of the tin-can  Mona Lisa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, shit... (exhales deeply) I gotta pee anyway.

dialogues.speaker: INTERLUDE
dialogues.text: Grainy super 8 footage shows us an OLD MAN standing in fr of a small shack. His name is Lewis Dover. The shack is  painted white and covered with SIMPLISTIC RELIGIOUS WRITI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't no rich man, but I see the  truth. You do not have to go to Hell.  You are in Hell. This is Hell. All  American Hell. (holds up a gun) ...true heaven in my hands... I'm  gonna blow Satan back through the  door to Hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounding the shack are strange sculptures of various h human/half-animal creations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spaulding swabs up the last remains of blood from the flo he drops the mop into a bucket filled with water and bloo Bill pays no attention, he is distracted by a strange obj in a glass case over the counter. In the case is a shrive up looking half human and half fish figure. It is the siz of a small child. A banner above reads: AQUALINA - THE MERMAID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been running this  place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is a piece of string? Too  God damn long, that's how long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spaulding slides the mop and bucket behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I don't remember exactly. I  took over for my Pa just after the  Duke nabbed the Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, my Pa wasn't right in the head  after that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean John Wayne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, boy there some other Duke you  know about? (rolls up his sleeve  to reveal a John  Wayne tattoo) A great American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was never that big of a  western fan. I like science fiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured that much. Why the fuck  you asking so many jackass questions  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see me and my friends are writing  a book on offbeat roadside  attractions. You know all the crazy  shit you see when you drive cross  country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't drive cross country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But suppose for a second you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fake hick accent) Y'all find us country people real  funny like don't ya... well, God  damn pack up the mule and sling me  some grits, I'ze a gotta get me some  schooling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no I think it's really  interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well fuck me Side Sally, who want to  read about all that horse shit anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry OVERHEARS Bill's and Spaulding's conversation and j in to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised. Would it be OK  if we took some pictures and included  this place in our book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, knock yourself silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got some really rare stuff here... (pointing to Aqualina) ...dig your Feegee mermaid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The restroom is gray, dingy, a single exposed light bulb  hangs from the ceiling. The peeling walls are plastered w newspaper clippings and faded photos. Mary is in the stall, sitting on the toilet, staring stra ahead at a poster of RHONDO HATTON, a B-MOVIE ACTOR that  suffered from acromegalia. Denise standing at a tiny sink, splashes water on her fac She looks at herself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (water running down  her face) I swear I've aged five years since  this trip started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes a paper towel  and wipes her face) God, I hate falling asleep in the  afternoon. Now I'll be up all night... (stretches) ...ugh, my back is killing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, hey how far do you think we  are from your Dad's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary flushes the toilet and exits the stall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Couple hours I think.  I've got to call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary washes her hands. Denise ties up her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be nice to have a few days  off to regenerate. This trip is fun,  but it's starting to get brutal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I hit burn out mode back at  that old stripper lady's place.  Watching her dance around with those  ratty-looking animals was ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, that was some crazy shit. I  never in a million years would have  believed it if I hadn't seen it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A decent meal every once in a while  wouldn't hurt either, this road food  is crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I never eat at another Waffle  House again, I can die a happy girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scattered, smothered and covered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly... well, I guess a couple  more photos won't kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry knees over a box of magazines labeled TRUE CRIME $1 he flips through an issue, tosses it back. Bill leans against the wall next to him, sipping a hot cu of coffee. The girls return from the bathroom. Jerry jumps up with  excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, you're back. Let's go. We  already paid for the tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tickets for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't everything. Get ready for  this... there's a Museum of Murder  and Mayhem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about if we skip it and just  hang out here. I can get some great  shots of this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry PULLS Denise over and puts his arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, come on. It will be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, murder museum... sounds  fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill grabs Mary by the hand and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) We'll need pictures of the inside  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, alright. I know... I wanted  to be the photographer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Mary kiss. Spaulding waits, unamused. He rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anytime this year, people. Alright  line your asses up in front of the  black door. The tour is about to  begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spaulding disappears through a curtain behind the counter The kids wait. The black metal door CREAKS open. They enter the darkened room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. A blue light comes on. Spaulding is standing on MOTORIZED PLATFORM. He begins the tour, speaking through small megaphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, you are about  to enter a world of darkness. A world  where life and death are meaningless  and pain is God. (pointing with a cane) To your left you see the infamous  Albert Fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lifeless wax figure POPS forward with a loud metal CLAN Mary jumps back with fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadist, masochist, child killer and  most of all importantly cannibal.  Born in 1870, Mr. Fish enjoyed burning  himself with hot pokers, spankings  with nail-studded paddles and  embedding needles in his groin. On  the right, notice the X-ray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...showing clearly 29 sewing needles  inserted in to his groin. Mr. Fish  was executed in 1936 at the age of  65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spaulding rolls backwards and continues the tour. CLOSE UP ON: a dummy face of a grizzly looking old man in hunting attire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To your right. One of our most popular  crazies, the psycho of Plainfield,  Ed Gein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the figure of Gein hangs an inverted corpse of a s woman. Mary recoils in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murderer, cannibal and momma's little  bitch boy. Mr. Gein found special  pleasure in playing with the dead  bodies of women, especially their  sexual organs. He was quite a handy  little dandy, fashioning lamp shades,  jewelry and human skin suits from  his victims. Mr. Gein was discovered  when the decapitated body of Bernice  Worden was found gutted like a deer,  hanging in his barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wax figure of a young man in doctor's scrubs. He is cov in blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now I would like to introduce a  local hero, S. Quentin Quale, a.k.a.  The Butcher Boy, a.k.a. Nurse Nellie  and most famously a.k.a. Dr. Satan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another wax figure, of a bloody corpse, JUMPS up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murderer, torturer and most of all  master surgeon. Mr. Quale an intern  at Willows State Mental Hospital,  nicknamed Weeping Willows for its  neverending cries of pain, took great  pleasure in control. Through primitive  brain surgery. Mr. Quale believed he  could create a race of superhumans  from the mentally ill, or so the  story goes. His terrifying experiments  continued until 1952.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry stares fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At which time he was discovered and  turned over to authorities for  observation. Unfortunately, Mr. Quale  was abducted from his cell by members  of the victims' families. Vigilante  justice prevailed and Dr. Satan was  taken out and hanged. The next day  his body was found to be missing.  Some say he survived, rescued by his  loyal slaves, others say they hung  the wrong man... To this day no sign  of Dr. Satan has ever been discovered.  But who knows? Maybe he lives next  door to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KLUNK: A big metal door opens to the outside world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please exit through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids exit. SLAM! The door shuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise leans against the glass walls of the phone booth. Various flyers are taped to the inside: free kittens, pho sex ads and a missing poster for a girl named KAREN MURPH A light rain begins to fall. Denise puts some change in the phone and dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera moves down a quaint quiet little street. We co to rest at a modest two-story house. The house is decorat for Halloween. Parents and their children roam from house to house, tric or treating. We hear the sound of a phone ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grey haired man sits at a small table eating a ham sand and drinking a beer. This is DONALD WILLIS, Denise's fath He stands up and walks to the phone hanging on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... (brightens up) ...hey Denise... what, what's wrong,  did you break down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, nothing like that... yeah, we're  gonna be a little late. We stopped  for gas at this place called Capt.  Spaulding's outside of Ruggsville  and it turned into a whole thing, so  we're kind of behind schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, yeah I've driven by that  place before. I seem to remember a  crabby old bastard in a crummy clown  suit running the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well he's still here. I think  him and Jerry are fast becoming  buddies, you know Jerry... yeah,  he's gotta see everything... yeah, I  know... thinks there's some unsolved  mystery around every corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't take too long, the kids  are already knocking down the door  demanding their sugar fix... I know,  I know I forgot to mention that  Halloween falls on a school night,  so they're trick or treating  tonight... I got the joint decked  out this year, built a graveyard in  the front yard like when you were a  kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopefully I can move things along  here and make up the lost time by  speeding all the way home... yes,  Dad I'm kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, just promise me you'll be  careful... alright, alright see ya  soon... good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, Jerry and Mary wait for Denise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, come on Jerry. We've gotten all  we're gonna get out of this place  and its starting to rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, it is only sprinkling and it's  worth the trouble. Hold on for two  seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry goes back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry knocks on the glass as he passes. Denise waves as h walks by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah so... OK, expect us more around  eleven or so. OK yeah, I will...  love you, too, bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up the phone, opens the doors and heads back to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's hard to understand, but  I really want to see this tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, alright I'll draw you a map, but  I still say it is a waste of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window we see Jerry talking to Spaulding.   Spaulding draws a map, explaining as he draws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geez, he never gets tired does he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never. I swear to God he never sleeps,  he goes to bed after me, wakes up  before me. He's always working on  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's a cyborg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily, sips his  coffee) I like sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry comes bouncing out towards the car and jumps in. He is holding a map and a box of chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hit the jackpot! Let's roll, good  buddy. We got ourselves a convoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh, what's that smell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fried chicken. (holds up a drumstick) Anybody want some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one responds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLD FARMER and his WIFE stare directly into the camera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where that skunk ape  sleeps. Maybe in the trees and all...  all I know is he eats squirrels to  survive and he had impure relations  with my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true. He performed lurid acts  upon me and my person while my husband  Russell was a fix'n to our hound  Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I see that thing again... I'm a  gonna kill that skunk ape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off screen) What does it look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looked just like that chubby fella  from McHale's Navy... Ernie Borgnine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold up the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wife holds up a pencil sketch of a Bigfoot like creat and a newspaper photo of Ernest Borgnine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill's car moves past empty farmlands. A HEAVIER RAIN is falling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry directs Bill from Spaulding's hand-drawn map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep straight on this road here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much further?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not exactly sure... it looks  close. Did we pass an abandoned school  bus yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Denise sit bundled up in blankets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just skip it. It is probably  nothing anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw Christ, Jerry. We can't see  anything now, it's too dark. Let's  forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we need something like this.  It could be the real deal. It's too  far out of the way to come back to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windshield we see a LONE FIGURE hitch-hiking the side of the road. It is a girl, BABY, 27, in a worn c hat and long fur coat. She is soaked to the bone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hitchhiker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't even think about playing  the good samaritan, there's way too  many psychos wandering loose these  days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking closer) It's a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, maybe she knows where this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) That seems likely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't leave her out here in the  rain... maybe we can just drop her  at the next rest area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks like a freak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick her in the front, if you want  to pick her up so bad. She's soaked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks like she stinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Mary) She looks like she stinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (makes cat noises) Cat fight, cat fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardy har, har.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls over and Baby jumps in. The car moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once inside the car they see that the girl is a bit odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, thanks for stopping. I been  standing out there in that toad  strangling rain for like a hundred  million years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, that's a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, most people just whiz on by  like I was invisible or something...  or else they're creeps who wanna jam  their slimy hands down my pants and  twiddle my naughty-naughty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, icky. This one guy stops and I  look in and he's got his thing out  waving it around like a drunk monkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hitchhiking ain't the safest  way for a girl to travel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it's fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a magical trip through  the heartland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where ya headed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, I was going home to my Mamma's  house... yeah, I was out doing this  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple more miles up this road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you might know... (shows her the map) ...you know where this tree is at?  It's an old hanging tree from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baby PERKS UP at the mention of the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know where that is, it's  right by my house. It's Dr. Satan's  tree. I can show ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, wow, so it's really a real  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's a tree. I used to play  there all the time. But, you can't  find it without me. Outsider can't  find no deadwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deadwood, is that what it's called?  Cool, will you show us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, maybe, maybe... hey, you know  what word I hate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh... what cone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any cone, yeah... (looking out the window) I hate that word... sounds ugly, I  don't like crumple either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always hate saying the word cheese,  every time you get your picture  taken... smile, say cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I hate Swiss cheese, the holes  make me nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the tree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is crazy. She don't know nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby turns her attention toward Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know. I'll show you where it's  at, sweetie. Aren't you just so cute  all bundled up like a cinnamon roll  of Christmas love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go straight up about another mile...  til we hit Cherrypicker Road and  turn right... it ain't far from there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera FLOATS through the hallways of the Peabody Men Institution. It is HALLOWEEN. PATIENTS wander the stark halls dressed in hospital gowns and cheap plastic masks. Some are laughing, some are  screaming. We move into a private room. Where we see DOCTOR SATAN  completely covered except for his eyes, hovering over a B AND GAGGED PATIENT. We move off the doctor to a crayon child's DRAWING of a J O'-LANTERN. Tortured screams fill the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a STRANGER'S POV we see the car STRUGGLING down a di road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone rides in silence, music plays on the radio. The song ends and a NEWS REPORTER comes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is WJRC News at the top of the  hour... Investigators in Clairemont  County are no closer to identifying  the body of a young woman found  crucified to the doors of St. Mary's  Church yesterday morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby lights up a cigarette and takes a drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, could you not smoke in  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby puts out the cigarette on the back of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Local police and State Officials  have released this report...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Looks like some kind  of animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting dead center in the middle of the road is a HUMONG DOG. The dog stares straight ahead. Long strands of drool hang from its mouth to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we stopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a dog in the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honk at him. Scare him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (honking horn) He won't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not enough room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then run him over, he'll move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! He's one of God's creatures, he  can't help it if he's dumb... I'm  just crazy about animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Denise) The animals have got nothing to do  with it.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: A gun barrel is raised and we are looking through the sig at the car. Pop! Pop! Pop! The GUN fires THREE SHOTS at t car's rear tire. The stranger whistles and the dog moves to the side of th road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of the heavy rain MASKS the gunshots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, he moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get going before that thing  tries to eat the car or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car moves past, Denise stares at the dog sitting c to the side of the road. The dog blankly stares back at h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That reminds me of a film I saw once  of a guy who got out of his car at  Lion Country Safari to take a picture  of a lion cub and got eaten by the  lions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I heard about that. I always  thought it was bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... yeah, they ripped him to pieces  while his family watched from the  car. The wife is screaming, the kids  are crying. Some dude in another car  filmed the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lions were totally covered in  this guy's blood... I think they ate  his face off, tore open his rib cage,  pulled his legs off... it was a wild  scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things like that get a lot bloodier  than ya think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without warning the car lunges to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. I think we blew a tire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to be fucking joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it, I knew this witch-hunt  was fucking bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, let's relax. I'll check it, maybe  I'm wrong. Don't everybody freak out  just yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll help ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Gee, ya think it wouldn't be too  much trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Jerry stare down at the blown tire sunk in the m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you fixed the spare like I  asked ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I fixed it. Well, I ain't...  um, I can't remember. I think I took  it out to fit the bags and forgot to  put it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, technically I did what ya said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a real fucking piece of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill stares at Jerry in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby is leaning on her chin staring at Mary and Denise. T car radio plays in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you with something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wondering what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you two gals all funny with each  other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know... a couple of queers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe this fucking girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning her attention  to Mary) I was just wondering, cause you got  a pissy look about you... like a  real pussy licking bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise tries to QUICKLY defuse the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No pussy licking here, but thanks  for your concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Jerry slide back into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I got some bad news and some  bad news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fake Scottish accent) Tire's fucking gone crap on us, man.  There's no saving it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the spare is safely sitting in  Jerry's garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For fucking sake Jerry, what the  fuck are we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby starts laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you laughing about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just pictured the tire sitting in  a chair watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wonderful. (muttering to herself) Fucking psycho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'll try to back it out on  the rim... at least to the main road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you keep going straight you can  get back on the interstate... it's  easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should go straight. I  mean we know for a fact there ain't  nothing back that way, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh wait! I love this song!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby reaches over and TURNS UP the VOLUME. She loudly sin along with the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll go straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the loud music) Fine! I'll go straight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car moves forward. After about fifty yards the car HI something hard and gets stuck in a deep mud bog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck! We are fucked!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn that fucking radio off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill shuts off the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what are we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can walk to my house from here.  My brother's got a tow truck, he can  come get your car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence falls over the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm going fucking crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, whatever. Let's go get your  brother's truck. Faster we get the  truck, faster we get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go. It's my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said it, not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. I'll just go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw that, no way, I ain't letting  you go by yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'll be quick. Just  stay here, no sense everybody getting  drenched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it won't take long and besides  you sassy poodle girls will slow us  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby jumps up and gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget the flashlight, it's  pretty dark out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill kisses Mary good-bye and EXITS. Mary watches Baby and Bill head off into the WOODS. Baby  turns and makes a kissy face at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand painted tin sign surrounded by flashing lights whi reads MISS BUNNY'S HOLLYWOOD REVUE hangs over the entranc to a small garage. Movie star portraits of JEAN HARLOW, W.C. FIELDS and CLAR GABLE adorn the walls of the garage. An over the hill ex-glamour girl, MISS BUNNY, 55, comes i frame. She's dressed in a sparkling red gown with feather in her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bad Marilyn Monroe  imitation) Hi, I'm Miss Bunny and welcome to my  Hollywood Revue... (she giggles) ...where the stars shine forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tinseltown lives. Tin foil is wrapped around everything, walls, doors and ceiling. Fake cement handprints of movie greats cover the tiny floor. Badly sculpted statues of MA MONROE, GROUCHO MARX and JOHN WAYNE stand in the corners. Dead center is a small puppet show stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, this is the place where the magic  happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stuffed squirrel dressed in a gray skirt and jacket, a  tilted hat sits atop its head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up squirrel) This is Jenny, she is our resident  Ingrid Bergman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bunny picks up a stuffed white cat wearing a brown  trenchcoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Ronald J. Perrywinckle...  our Humphrey Bogart... today we'll  be doing a scene from Casablanca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bunny begins to make the dead animal puppets interac She provides their voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that plane leaves the ground and  you're not with him you'll regret  it... maybe not today, maybe not  tomorrow but soon and for the rest  of your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll always have Paris. We didn't  have, we lost it... until you came  to Casablanca. We got it back last  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I said I would never leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you never will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single flashlight beam cuts through the darkness of the dense woods. Bill stumbles behind Baby, she is clearly in her element.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much further?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost there... are you in a hurry  or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, kind of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry is stretched out across the front seat, reading a b on Freak Shows. Denise and Mary sit in the back, curled u under layers of blankets and clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck, it's freezing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, listen to this... I think this  is related to our Dr. Satan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, in this book there's a chapter  called Self Made Freaks about how  people would mutilate themselves in  order to work in a freak show. It  mostly talks about tattooed people  and wild men of Borneo and shit like  that, but there is one mention of a  single case where a woman was  suspected of having her arms removed  on purpose to become an arm-less  wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, so how does that fit with the  story of four morons with a flat  tire looking for a dead tree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says, "records show that Ellie  Thompson was born in 1914 of normal  physical stature and lived a life of  normal bearings, until such time  that she was placed in the care of  the Willows State Mental Facility."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now she was put in the nuthouse in  1930 at the age of 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scanning the book) Blah, blah, blah... it doesn't say,  but she was released sometime in  1937, only to reappear as Ellie  Bogdan, the arm-less wonder. Says  she, "criss-crossed the United States  constantly in carnivals and freak  shows until her death in 1946."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These dates perfectly correspond  with the time frame of our beloved  Dr. Satan working at the looney bin.  I'll bet he amputated her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I just thought it was  interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what Jerry, who really cares  at this point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't... (to himself) ...I just thought it was weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bursting in) God damn it, I must be fucking crazy  to let him go off with that crazy  fucking bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That stupid hillbilly slut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't blow everything out of  proportion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't see the look she threw  me. She's up to something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Jerry, she said some pretty  fucked shit to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you were outside with Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said we look like pussy lickers  or some shit like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, she said we looked queer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, get over it, she's just some  dopey redneck, she ain't smart enough  to be up to nothing... I mean  anything... chicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old Gothic FARMHOUSE stands atop a hill at the end of long sloping dirt road. SCARECROWS with pumpkin heads han CRUCIFIED on crosses lining the drive. Everything is seve overgrown. Bill and Baby enter the gates of the FARM, they walk up t main drive. Baby runs forward and begins jumping around in the huge m puddles, then runs up onto the front porch of the old hou The front of the house is covered with strange junk art.  Hundreds of dolls faces are nailed to the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are all my dolls. I use to  like to chop their heads off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broken bottles and cans are cemented together in weird HU FIGURES, ANIMAL SKINS stretched over bone armatures form makeshift roof. Glowing down from the upper windows are grinning JACK-O'- LANTERNS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door's locked. I'll gotta go  around... wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby RUNS OFF around the side of the house. Bill stands looking off into the distance at the desolate farm grounds. The rain continues to hammer down. From BILL'S POV we see a silhouette of a LONE FIGURE walk in the distance. The shape of a large dog follows behind  him. Bill JUMPS, startled by the sound of the heavy front door opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, you scared the shit out of  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, you ain't seen nothing yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your brother ready to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... yeah, he already left. We'll  wait inside, come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby GRABS Bill by the arm and pulls him into the house. The heavy iron door slams shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise and Mary sit facing one another, playing cards. Mary deals from a deck. Jerry naps in the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has it been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... about half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A metal KLANG is faintly heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I didn't hear anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... quiet. Turn off the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary reaches over the front seat and turns off the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now... listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hear anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Shhhhhh, quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn on the headlights. See if  anything is out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns on the headlights. Denise lets out a blood-cur SCREAM. Jerry bolts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What... what!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing dead center in the road is the GIANT SHAPE of a holding a heavy chain with a huge hook on the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock the doors... quick, quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody scrambles to lock the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy fuck, holy fuck, holy fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On closer inspection, Jerry notices the chain is attached the back of a TOW TRUCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, hold on! Everybody calm  down! It's the tow truck guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm gonna have a fucking  heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Scottish accent) OK lassies, I think it's time you  get to gripping reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough with the stupid voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brute man attaches the chain to the car and begins ra it with his truck. A SIGN on the side of the truck reads FIREFLY TOWING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are watching a scene from THE OLD DARK HOUSE. GLORIA  STUART, RAYMOND MASSEY and MELVYN DOUGLAS are standing in the rain pounding on a huge wooden door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock again louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should of thought that was loud  enough to wake the dead... that's an  idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be dramatic, supposing  the people inside were dead. All  stretched out with the lights quietly  burning about them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it would be very amusing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back from the TV to see Bill's clothes drying by fireplace. Bill, now wearing overalls and a flannel shirt is sitting on an old over stuffed sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you live here alone... I mean  with just your brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking from the  next room) No. There's a bunch a us 'round  somewhere... I think Mamma's sleepin'.  She sleeps a lot, now... do you want  marshmallows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, yeah sure, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure do a lot of guessing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby sets down the tray, making sure to bend over close t Bill. She hands him his drink and sits down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby moves closer to Bill, he begins to get nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, um... (pointing to the  mounted animal head  over the fireplace) ...what kind of animal is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dead one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sipping his drink) Mmmmm, this is tasty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scoops out some  marshmallow with her  finger) Ain't the only thing tasty in this  house. (licks it off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what time it is. Seems kind  of late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, sugar. It ain't past my  bedtime... are you flirting with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No, I'm was worried that... I  was just wondering what's taking so  long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Maybe R.J. got into a crash and  killed everbody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not something to joke about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolls her eyes) OK, sorry... maybe the Great Pumpkin  ate 'em up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, the SOUND OF A TRUCK pulling up can be HEARD. Bill jumps up and goes to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, great they're back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Whoopie fucking doo.

dialogues.speaker: TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: On the B+W screen we see DR. WOLFENSTEIN, a local horror  movie host. He looks like a cross between the WOLFMAN and LON CHANEY in LONDON AFTER MIDNIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sounds like Wolfman  Jack) Aaaahooooh, the Doctor is in! Don't  move, don't scream. Stay tuned for  more creature craziness from channel  68's Halloween eve movie marathon.  I'm your host... your ghost host  with the most, baby... Dr. Wolfenstein  and will be with you until the end.  Aaaaaaahooooooh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill stands on the front porch watching as the truck roug jerks the car to a stop. Jerry jumps out, opens the back door and helps Denise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Bill) Hey, nice outfit Billy Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming to get us. Little  brother almost scared us to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to Bill as  he passes) Dude, your chick's a little high  strung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is the last one out of the car. She says nothing as walks to join the others on the porch. Her look says it all as she walks by Bill and into the ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, I'm sorry but he left without  me. Mary... come on, you don't think  I'd leave you stranded out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone stands around at the fireplace, trying to dry of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. I gotta call my Dad and tell  him we're gonna be late. Can I use  your phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby sits silently watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, may I please use your  phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Bill, why don't you ask her... she's  your special friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VOICE from upstairs answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't got one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOTHER comes into view from the darkness above. She is in her fifties, but looks younger. A sleazy white trash quee She slowly descends the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, hi. You really don't have a  phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, none. I had one once, back in  '57 maybe... I don't know. Really  ain't nobody we wanna be jaw flapping  at around here no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, maybe the guy with the tow truck  could drive us to a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Rufus, Rufus Jr., but we  all call him R.J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they call you, sweety?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I'm Jerry... that's Bill... Denise  and Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe R.J. could just tow us  and our car to the nearest garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean obviously we will compensate  you for your troubles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you ain't no troubles, no, no,  no fuss. (claps her hands) Baby... go see what Rufus Jr. is  doing with these nice folks'  automobile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby slowly rises like a defiant child and walks out of t room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the meanwhile please make  yourselves at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gruesome crime scene photos flash across the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing, off screen) 98 bodies in your bed, Some are green,  some are red. Eat the flesh and pick  the bones, Drink the blood when you  get home. 99 bodies in the ground,  Some are blue, some are brown. Gather  'round the people said, Where do you  go when you are dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, Jerry, Denise and Mary are all seated on the sofa Bill sits in an easy chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what brings you kids way out  here, ain't you got something better  to do for Halloween than wander around  out here in the sticks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I thought I'd maybe take in a  hoedown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flirting) Oh, really... (puts her hand on  Jerry's knee and  winks) ...well, I'm a pretty good dancer if  you know what I mean... I bet I got  a few moves you ain't never seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's just joking. We don't really  have any plans other than spending  the night at my Dad's house... (glances at Jerry) ...which is where we were headed  when our car broke down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess I'll just help him  hand out candy to the trick or  treaters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm gonna help put the razor  blades in the candy apples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet you are... you are a naughty  little thing aren't ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Mary snicker at Jerry's comments. Denise tries t keep a straight face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I get it... I guess you think  you're too good for the simple  pleasures of Halloween.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, just a little too old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really, well I hope something  changes your mind some day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby returns from the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiny's home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about R.J.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he was already gone before I  seen him... but Tiny saw him and  said he said he was going out to the  yard to get a new wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The yard, what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an old auto junkyard out in  Baldwin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is that gonna take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should be back in a couple hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple hours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Tiny drive us to a phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother and Baby laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Tiny ain't got no car, he ain't even  got a bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's he get around out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks, duh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're my guests and welcome  but I'd please advise you to keep  from cussing while in my house, thank  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, even though I know it seems  childish to you all. Tonight is  Halloween eve and it special to us  so you are all invited to stay for  dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the circumstances they realize they have no choice. They grin and bear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitates Elvis) Yes, thank you. Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mother touches Jerry's  shoulder suggestively) You're a strange one, aren't ya honey.  I think you and me are get on like... (she thinks for a  second) ...like something real good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera moves over to the TV. THE END fades up on screen. Dr. Wolfenstein appears over the credits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There well, who knew there was love  to be found in The Old Dark House.  Coming up next, do not move a muscle,  an artery or a vein as we venture  into another creepy classic... are  you ready for THE WOLFMAN, baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, Jerry, Mary and Denise are now all seated around a  large dining room table. A thick mountain of candles sits burning dead center on the table, giving off a warm glow. Dozens of Halloween decorations dangle from strings over table, spiders, bats and black cats. There is a hand-made PAPER MACHE MASK sitting on each pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up the witch  mask) I hope to Christ she doesn't expect  us to wear these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it is just do it. The more  we play along the faster we'll get  the hell out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, now is not the time to make  waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm just waiting for Cousin Itt  to show up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhhhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother walks in holding a covered serving tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you don't need any help in  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No dear, I'm fine. Now what kind of  host would I be if I put my guests  to this kind of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sets the tray and goes back in the kitchen. BOOM! The sound of the front door SLAMMING shut is heard, followed by the POUNDING of heavy footsteps. Mother's and Baby's shouting is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma, Tiny's in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go tell him to get your Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby is standing in front of her closet staring at her  clothes. The walls of her room are covered with B+W photo of movie stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whining) Ma, I can't, I'm busy getting dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINY ENTERS and removes his coat. Everyone is speechless. Tiny is over SEVEN FEET TALL and weighs THREE HUNDRED POU He is wearing a black sweater with a big red skull stitch into it. A red knit ski mask covers his face. Black glove cover his hands. Tiny sits at the table, looks down at his plate and says  nothing. Mother comes to fetch Tiny. She relays a message to him w strange hand gestures. Tiny gets up and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to forgive Tiny, he can't  hear so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, my poor baby. It's his Daddy's  fault. I mean Earl was a good man...  I mean he never hit me or nothing,  but one day he just got up and went  pure devil on us all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? Oh, I'm sorry, it's  none of my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tried to burn the house down,  said it was possessed by the spirits.  Tiny was sleeping in the basement  where the fire started. I don't think  Earl ever meant to harm us... but  Tiny was badly burnt, his ears were  destroyed and most of his skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why he wears the mask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, my baby boy gets shy around  new people, but he'll warm up to  ya... especially the ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I thought I felt a certain  attraction between Mary and Tiny  soon as he walked in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. He's a real lady killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't ya think, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary just smiles, then gives Jerry a dirty look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we'll see... the night is young  and so are you... oh well, couple  more minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother returns to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (elbows Jerry) Don't be such a fucking smart ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's really your fault that  we're stuck in this shithole in the  first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't worry she didn't get  offended by what I said. You two got  to lighten up... right, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever, at this point all I care  about is food. I'm starving and I  got a fucking killer headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I asked you if you wanted some  chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't look like chicken to me, more  like fried pussy cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Tasted pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a cramped, darkened room we see the huge shape of Tiny hovering over a BED containing the hunched, fragile old b of GRAMPA. Grampa struggles to sit, then slowly slides his legs over the edge of the bed. Tiny helps him to stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it, I can do it. I can do  it myself, ya big monkey. I ain't  dead yet... so don't you and your  sister start counting out my money  yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grampa steadies himself against Tiny. They slowly walk ou of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn, my dogs are barking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they move into the light of the hallway, it is clear t Grampa is in his late 80's. Grampa quickly grows tired. Tiny picks him up in his arms and carries him down the stairs to the dining room. As they move past, the camera comes to rest on a STRANGE  OBJECT sitting on a shelf.
